title: Martin Keown claims Liverpool proved they can become champions with Man Utd draw
text:

Martin Keown has told Liverpool they must "embrace" being the Premier League champions in waiting after proving they have what it takes to win it.

The former Arsenal defender commended the way Liverpool earned a hard-fought point at Old Trafford on Sunday, after being frustrated by Man Utd for much of the match.

Liverpool were a goal down as the game entered its closing stages, when substitute Adam Lallana popped up with a late equaliser.

But Keown warned the Merseyside club that they must start behaving like champions if they are to become them.

He told the Mail : "Liverpool need to learn to enjoy the situation they are in. Yes, every man and his dog may be prematurely putting a crown on your heads, but you have to embrace that.

(Image: Getty Images)

"Relish the pedestal you’re being put on. Liverpool lacked that mentality yesterday. They did not turn up at Old Trafford looking like a team that had won their last 17 Premier League games. They didn’t swagger in there like champions in waiting."

Keown did give credit to United for the way they set about shackling Liverpool and pressing them at every opportunity.

United were underdogs going into the match, but found themselves in front after Marcus Rashford turned in Daniel James cross.

There was controversy in the build-up to the goal, as Liverpool complained about a foul on Divock Origi which went unpunished as United broke away to score.

(Image: Getty Images)

Sadio Mane then had a goal disallowed as it looked increasingly like it wasn't going to be Liverpool's day.

The Reds had gone into the clash needing just a win to equal the record for consecutive Premier League victories held by Man City.

But they struggled to get their usual flowing passing game going, until Lallana's late leveller spared their blushes.

Keown added: "It took Liverpool a while to sort themselves out but Klopp used his substitutes well and they got something out of this game. That at least suggests they can become champions."
description: The Reds are six points clear after rescuing a point at Old Trafford thanks to a late goal from substitute Adam Lallana
